Summary: The proposal introduces AdaCompose, a unified framework for continual adaptation across transfer learning, meta-learning, and lifelong learning. It addresses limitations like catastrophic forgetting, negative transfer, and scalability through dynamic parameter composition, task-relational hypernetworks, and a transformer-based memory system. The experiment plan includes evaluations on transfer efficiency, meta-learning scalability, lifelong learning stress tests, memory efficiency, and real-world deployment.
Strengths: Clear problem statement identifying key limitations in existing paradigms.
Ambitious hypothesis proposing a unified solution.
Innovative combination of hypernetworks, meta-learning, and memory systems.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering multiple benchmarks and metrics.
Weaknesses: Feasibility concerns regarding computational overhead and scalability.
Lack of critical discussion on potential technical challenges and risks.
Novelty is somewhat incremental, building heavily on existing work.
Experiment plan lacks depth in addressing how key technical barriers will be overcome.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of task-relational hypernetworks and transformer-based memory systems be managed?
What are the specific mechanisms to ensure the transformer-based memory system scales to thousands of tasks?
How will the framework handle extreme domain shifts not seen during meta-training?
What are the fallback mechanisms if any core component fails?
Limitations: Potential high computational cost due to hypernetworks and transformer memory.
Scalability of the memory system to very large task sequences.
Risk of overfitting in meta-learning due to memory replay.
Real-world deployment may reveal unforeseen bottlenecks.
